Curator's comments: See John Petherick, 'Egypt, the Soudan and Central Africa', 1861, p.160 (Kordofan) ‘The rachat, a girl’s dress, appeard to be a larger item of native industry and is made from kid-skins. The fringe in some of them consisted of thousands of small strips of leather of equal thickness, about one foot in length, and was supplied with plaited strips to which were attached several tassels, and ornamented with rings of zinc and a few coral and amber beads; the whole when worn, suspended to the waist-girdle at each hip, all but touching the ground. Cf. Mr & Mrs Petherick, 'Travels in Central Africa', 1869, I p.121.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Sir Augustus Wollaston Franks
